messages.text:
messing with the RC acausal tutorial. I'm trying to make a circuit with a bunch of resistors in series. I'm wondering if this is right. functions left undefined are from <https://mtk.sciml.ai/dev/tutorials/acausal_components/|here>
```N = 10
R = rand(N)
V = 1.0
resistors= []
for i in eachindex(R)
    sys = Resistor(;name=Symbol("r_", i), R=R[i])
    push!(resistors, sys)
end

@named source = ConstantVoltage(V=V)
@named ground = Ground()

r_eqs = [
          connect_pins(source.p, resistors[1].p)
          [connect_pins(resistors[i].n, resistors[i+1].p) for i in 1:(N-1)]...
          connect_pins(resistors[N].n, source.n, ground.g)
         ]

@named r_model = ODESystem(r_eqs, t,
                            systems=[resistors..., source, ground])

sys = structural_simplify(r_model)```
I think it's right, but i'm not sure if this is the best way

elements.text: messing with the RC acausal tutorial. I'm trying to make a circuit with a bunch of resistors in series. I'm wondering if this is right. functions left undefined are from
here

N = 10
R = rand(N)
V = 1.0
resistors= []
for i in eachindex(R)
    sys = Resistor(;name=Symbol("r_", i), R=R[i])
    push!(resistors, sys)
end

@named source = ConstantVoltage(V=V)
@named ground = Ground()

r_eqs = [
          connect_pins(source.p, resistors[1].p)
          [connect_pins(resistors[i].n, resistors[i+1].p) for i in 1:(N-1)]...
          connect_pins(resistors[N].n, source.n, ground.g)
         ]

@named r_model = ODESystem(r_eqs, t,
                            systems=[resistors..., source, ground])

sys = structural_simplify(r_model)
I think it's right, but i'm not sure if this is the best way

messages.text: One major difference between MTK and Modelica is that we don’t use ad-hoc keywords or syntaxes to express something that can be expressed in a general programming language.  `@blocknamed` won’t be a trivial syntactic transformation like `@named`. Though, we can provide something like `arrayname(x::Symbol, i::Integer) = Symbol(x, (reverse(digits(100)) .+ '₀')...); arrayname(x, i::Integer) = Symbol(nameof(x), i);`

elements.text: One major difference between MTK and Modelica is that we don’t use ad-hoc keywords or syntaxes to express something that can be expressed in a general programming language.
@blocknamed
won’t be a trivial syntactic transformation like
@named
. Though, we can provide something like
arrayname(x::Symbol, i::Integer) = Symbol(x, (reverse(digits(100)) .+ '₀')...); arrayname(x, i::Integer) = Symbol(nameof(x), i);

messages.text:
Also, consider
```julia> @variables t xs[1:2](t)
(t, Num[xs₁(t), xs₂(t)])

julia> states(ODESystem([D(xs[1]) ~ xs[1]; D(xs[2]) ~ xs[1] + xs[2]^2], t))
2-element Vector{Term{Real, Nothing}}:
 xs₁(t)
 xs₂(t)```
What would `states` be with array variables? Since it they are explicitly indexed, it’s not different from scalar code.

elements.text: Also, consider

julia> @variables t xs[1:2](t)
(t, Num[xs₁(t), xs₂(t)])

2-element Vector{Term{Real, Nothing}}:
 xs₁(t)
 xs₂(t)

states
be with array variables? Since it they are explicitly indexed, it’s not different from scalar code.

messages.text: Vague question: Are there any good references to understand how to organize a FEM-discretized PDE? I don't think this matters serially but I think it matters a lot for blocking on integration on GPUs. Vaguely it seems like I should organize by a graph coloring so that same-colored nodes are executing and integrating simultaneously, but I'm sure there's more to it than that. Thanks!

elements.text: Vague question: Are there any good references to understand how to organize a FEM-discretized PDE? I don't think this matters serially but I think it matters a lot for blocking on integration on GPUs. Vaguely it seems like I should organize by a graph coloring so that same-colored nodes are executing and integrating simultaneously, but I'm sure there's more to it than that. Thanks!

messages.text: Is there a design reason that MTK systems seem to only allow subsystems of the same type? For composing ReactionSystems it seems like it would be nice to allow NonlinearSystems and maybe ODESystems as subsystems, but I don’t want to go that route if there is a fundamental issue with doing that.

elements.text: Is there a design reason that MTK systems seem to only allow subsystems of the same type? For composing ReactionSystems it seems like it would be nice to allow NonlinearSystems and maybe ODESystems as subsystems, but I don’t want to go that route if there is a fundamental issue with doing that.

messages.text: <https://github.com/SciML/ModelingToolkit.jl/issues/817>
Cool, so the answer is we just haven’t supported it yet.

elements.text: Cool, so the answer is we just haven’t supported it yet.

messages.text: yeah. We should get it in like a month of so

messages.text: We need to setup a whole model promotion system to make it robust, and NonlinearSystem->ODESystem is the first one we'll do.

elements.text: We need to setup a whole model promotion system to make it robust, and NonlinearSystem->ODESystem is the first one we'll do.

messages.text: I think I’ll just require ODESystem when mixing with ReactionSystem then for now. We should immediately be able to at least hook into the component-based modeling for ODEs when converting then. Jumps still need work to support this (and I guess SDEs).

elements.text: I think I’ll just require ODESystem when mixing with ReactionSystem then for now. We should immediately be able to at least hook into the component-based modeling for ODEs when converting then. Jumps still need work to support this (and I guess SDEs).

messages.text: I think you're using the term stiff in a different way than other people in DiffEq might use the word stiff

elements.text: I think you're using the term stiff in a different way than other people in DiffEq might use the word stiff

messages.text:
i.e. In Diff Eq. stiff refers to <https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stiff_equation> (i.e. equations are stiff, numbers are not usually called stiff)

As to your question: for parameters p in a function like `predatorprey!(du,  u, p, t)` usually the parameters `p`
 do not change during one run of the solve. But in SciML one of the goals is (in my understanding) to usually try to optimize p in a way. So p can change over several different runs so that it gets optimized

elements.text: i.e. In Diff Eq. stiff refers to

(i.e. equations are stiff, numbers are not usually called stiff)

As to your question: for parameters p in a function like
predatorprey!(du,  u, p, t)
usually the parameters
p

do not change during one run of the solve. But in SciML one of the goals is (in my understanding) to usually try to optimize p in a way. So p can change over several different runs so that it gets optimized

messages.text:
```function Pendulum(;name, g = 9.81, L = 1.)
    gval = g
    Lval = L
    D = Differential(t)
    D2 = Differential(t)^2
    @variables x(t) y(t) T(t)
    @parameters g L
    eqs = [
        D(x) ~ D2(x)
        D2(x) ~ x*T
        D(y) ~ D2(y)
        D2(y) ~ y*T - g
        0 ~ x^2 + y^2 - (L^2)
    ]

    ODESystem(eqs, t, [x, y], [g, L], defaults=Dict([g, L].=>[gval, Lval]), name=name)
end```
does this look right for a Pendulum component?
following index reduction tutorial, but `structural_simplify` or `dae_index_lowering` is taking a while... (3 mins so far)

elements.text:
function Pendulum(;name, g = 9.81, L = 1.)
    gval = g
    Lval = L
    D = Differential(t)
    D2 = Differential(t)^2
    @variables x(t) y(t) T(t)
    @parameters g L
    eqs = [
        D(x) ~ D2(x)
        D2(x) ~ x*T
        D(y) ~ D2(y)
        D2(y) ~ y*T - g
        0 ~ x^2 + y^2 - (L^2)
    ]

    ODESystem(eqs, t, [x, y], [g, L], defaults=Dict([g, L].=>[gval, Lval]), name=name)
end

does this look right for a Pendulum component?
following index reduction tutorial, but
structural_simplify
or
dae_index_lowering
is taking a while... (3 mins so far)
